review.title: GeoGebra Tools with Proof Capabilities
review.abstract: We report about significant enhancements of the complex algebraic geometry theorem proving subsystem in GeoGebra for automated proofs in Euclidean geometry, concerning the extension of numerous GeoGebra tools with proof capabilities. As a result, a number of elementary theorems can be proven by using GeoGebra's intuitive user interface on various computer architectures including native Java and web based systems with JavaScript. We also provide a test suite for benchmarking our results with 200 test cases.

metadata.title: GeoGebra Tools with Proof Capabilities

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: GeoGebra is a mathematical software tool with millions of users. In 2005, its founder Markus Hohenwarter extended his software development to an open source project. GeoGebra's features (including dynamic geometry, computer algebra, spreadsheets and functional research) focus primarily on facilitating student experiments in Euclidean geometry rather than formal reasoning. The inclusion of automated derivative tools in GeoGebra's Dynamic Geometry System (DGS) could introduce a whole range of new learning and teaching scenarios. As automated theory proof (ATP) in geometry has reached a fairly mature stage, in 2010 some ATP experts agreed to launch a project to integrate and test various automated geometry examiners in GeoGebra. This collaboration was initiated by Toma's Recio. Since the first start of this project, this project has reached the following milestones: 1. Xiw2. Planning for a theoretical workshop in Santiago, Spain, 2013th.

sections.heading: 2 Overview
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it has never come as far as this year.

sections.heading: 3 Our enhancements
sections.text: We report on our contributions to GeoGebra in two important areas: 1. Implementing symbolic equations for various geometric tools (Section 3.1).2. Creating a series of tests to extend the benchmarks (Section 3.2).

sections.heading: 3.1 Symbolic equations
sections.text: GeoGebra's geometry tools were classified by [20, p. 104] as "easy to use," "medium" and "difficult to use." Preiner defines two criteria for a simple tool (p. 121): 1. The tool is not dependent on existing objects or only requires existing points that can also be created "on the fly" by clicking on the drawing pad. Here, too, the order of actions is irrelevant and no additional keyboard input is required. 2. The tool directly affects only one type of existing objects or all existing objects at once and requires only one action. Again, the order of actions is irrelevant and no additional keyboard input is required. The basic concept in our work was to implement theorem proving functions for the simpler tools in GeoGebra. Also, it was important that the commonly discussed theorems in the classroom can be constructed quickly by using the simpler tools. Theorem proving functions for the simpler tools in GeoGebra may require segments, segments in the classroom, and in the circles, and for some ellipses, and for segments in the circles.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Translating geometry to algebra
sections.text: The implementation of angles and cones can have theoretical difficulties in our approach. For angles, we refer to the fact that it is not possible to define only the inner bisector of an angle: we must always cooperate with internal and external angles at the same time (cf. [5, p. 40]). This is a consequence of the handling of angles: there is no way to verify the equality unless one calculates the tangent of them, that is, instead one must check whether one tan (α) = tan (β) and these formulas are equivalent only if we set some constraints, say 0 ≤ α, β < π. In this sense, we cannot distinguish between 0o and 180o.For cones, ellipses and hyperbolas, we must also be treated as indistinguishable objects, because we must define them with the synthetic approach, and the definitional relations are the same.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 The implemented tools
sections.text: Apart from taking these problems into account, we managed to handle many typical classroom situations, and we report that most "simple" tools are implemented, as well as some other tools from the "center" and "difficult to use" toolset.The following basic geometric shapes are now implemented: segment, line, beam and vector, each defined by two points, circle defined by center and passage point or by three points, angle, parabola with focus point and directional trix, ellipse and hyperbola defined by two focus points. This table summarizes them, and also those tools that can operate on the basic geometric shapes (the latter printed in italics, underlined objects are new improvements compared to [15]): tool description difficulty Implementation Notes Point easyLine easyCircle easyCircle easyCircle easyCircle segmented by 3 points easyCircle easylecular Circle easy sector Perasylect easy sector with easylepoint Midsector or easylepoint easypoint easypoint Bipenpoint.

sections.heading: 3.1.3 An example
sections.text: Theorem 2: vvvv2 is a circle with center A and circumference B. Leave a line through B and C. Now - without taking into account some degenerated cases - line a reflects over c the image is a circle, that is, for any point D-a its reflection D-a is always on the same circle (this is the circle of points A, B "(= B) and C," where B "and C" + are the mirror images of B and C above -c, respectively ---- * * * In other words, an inversion translates lines to circles in general. To use GeoGebras Relation Tool (see Figure 2), one must configure the construction as described in the algebra view on the left (either by selecting tools from the top or by using commands in the input bar on the bottom). Finally, one must select the Relation Tool from above and vvvvvvvvv2 vvvvv2 type 2 (type in the command D).

sections.heading: 3.1.4 Technical notes
sections.text: Technically, GeoGebra is a Java application. From the developer's point of view, the public Java interface SymbolicParametersBotanaAlgo must be implemented in GeoGebra's Algo * classes by creating appropriate algebraic equations (and corresponding new variables) to describe the symbolic background of a newly used tool.2To verify the validity of a work, the public interface SymbolicParametersBotanaAlgoAre must be implemented.3 Currently, the following checks are being carried out: collinearity, conformity, conformity, equality, parallelism, perpendicularity, frequency and formula verification (to prove equations).

sections.heading: 3.2 Benchmarks
sections.text: In our enhancements, a further 140 theorems have been added to the benchmark suite. 57 of these additional tests have been selected [5] - these tests were calculated in Chou's book using Wu's characteristic method. Here, we summarize our results by sharing a list of recent benchmarking results. GeoGebra's prover benchmarking system is available as a command-line tool in its source folder test / scripts / benchmark / prover /.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Desktop version
sections.text: The GeoGebra version runs as a native Java application on the most commonly used operating system platforms such as Windows, Mac OS X and Linux. • The following table is the output of the "Jar-Paper" scenario running from the command line xvfb-run. • The first column shortens the name of the test cases. • Column E1 ("Engine 1") refers to Recios exact check method used by Simon Weitzhofer.1The steps and the output for the calculation of this example have been simplified to fit this paper. See also [15] for the detailed symbolic check algorithms in the relation Tool.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Web version
sections.text: The web version runs in a web browser. All major browsers, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox and Internet Explorer are 564 angles. The following table was generated by typing the command line xvfb-run. / runtest -p "Auto Web" -r in this folder. It compares the results of the prove command in the desktop version ("Auto") and the web version ("Web").Test Auto WebR. S. R. S.lines-parallel f 7 f 11 midpoint-third 297 779 orthocente.. ar 303 626 points-col.. ar f 5 f 9 points-equal f 4 f 11Pythagoras.. n4 t 612 tangents-c.. ns 1153 t / o translate-.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Theorems in the classrooms
sections.text: In summary, we list some important theorems that are normally discussed in secondary schools. Now, they can be proved with GeoGebra's help, that is, for many theorems at least a yes / no answer is given, including: • The Pythagorean Theorem. The Section Theorem. The Geometric Mean and the Catheter Theorems. • Thales "Theorem. • Simultaneousness of Medians, Bisectors, Heights. Euler Line. The Centerline Theorem, Varignons Theorem. The Nine-Point Circle. Simsons Theorem. • The Angular Bisectoral Theorem. • Fundamental Properties of Translations and Rotations. • Fundamental Properties of Reflections on a Point, a Line or a Circle. • Cevas Theorem, Menelaus" Theorem. Desargues Theorem, Pappus "Theorem. • Fundamental Properties of Conical Sections (including Tangents). The underlined theorems can be demonstrated with the help of the Complex Allanemic Theorem, the use of Geogeometry.

sections.heading: 4 Future work
sections.text: Finally, we summarize the currently planned new features in the upcoming versions of GeoGebra.GeoGebra Tools Description To implementation Area of conicsTranslate by Vector line, segment, ray, circle, parabola, ellipse, hyperbola, polygonsReflect about Line ellipse, hyperbolaReflect about Circle lineRotate around Point general anglesThere is still room for further enhancements: • Improve formula handling by elimination non-square quantitations automatically and identifying formulas for a correct decision about the truth of the statement. • Current is not possible to mirror a line about a circle direct: In this case the implementation should handle that the object type is changing from line to circle in general. • The ShowProof command [13] might be implemented in cases when a readable proof can be automatic. • Allow proofs for 3D Euclidean geometry (cf. [21]).

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The Theorem Proving Subsystem in GeoGebra is a collaborative effort with contributions from several researchers, programmers and teachers. We are especially grateful to Bernard Parisse for improving the Giac CAS to compete with Singular and some commercial systems, which also provides GeoGebra with a robust embedded Theorem Prover. We are grateful to Toma's Recio, Predrag Janic, Julien Narboux and Francisco Botana for their useful hints on how to improve the text of this work, and to Markus Hohenwarter and Judit Robu for supporting our work.

referenceMentions.context: A prototype implementation was presented in Alcalá de Henares in June 2012 by demonstrating 44 test cases using 5 different theorem prover methods [2, 12].

Full documentation and fixing several issues according to users’ feedback in July 2015 in [15].
For example, GCLC [9] and OpenGeoProver [19] process a program code written in its special language and print the output as a precise report about the computation details.

Other systems including JGEX [24] and Cinderella [11] are not opensourced, but built upon a similar approach: visualizations in the DGS must be supported by ATP computations.
Other systems including JGEX [24] and Cinderella [11] are not opensourced, but built upon a similar approach: visualizations in the DGS must be supported by ATP computations.

GeoGebra’s command line interface with its Prove and ProveDetails commands and the graphical Relation Tool [16] introduce a higher level interface to investigate the problem setting by using an ATP subsystem.
A report [4] shows a benchmark about 60 theorems which can be directly checked with the Prove and ProveDetails commands in GeoGebra.
More details are shown in [14] about how the prover subsystem is embedded to GeoGebra’s user interface intuitively by using and extending the Relation Tool.
There are several approaches to compute a proof internally by using GeoGebra’s portfolio prover [13], including
• Wu’s method [23] by using OpenGeoProver externally, and also
With the help of the following computer algebra command we learn that for both the ellipse and the hyperbola we get the same product of 8th degree (here we used Giac [14] for computations):

This table summarizes them, and also those tools which can operate on the basic geometrical shapes (the latter ones printed in italicized description, underlined objects are new enhancements compared to [15]):
57 of these extra tests were chosen from [5]—these tests were computed in Chou’s book by using Wu’s [23] characteristic method.
57 of these extra tests were chosen from [5]—these tests were computed in Chou’s book by using Wu’s [23] characteristic method.
See also [15] for the detailed algorithm of symbolical checking in the Relation Tool.
See [4] for more details about the used methods.
• The best performing theorem prover—when using our corpus—is the complex algebraic geometry prover via Singular [8].
• The ShowProof command [13] might be implemented in cases when a readable proof can be produced automatically.
• GeoGebra’s LocusEquation command is capable of computing algebraic loci [3].

metadata.abstractText: We report about significant enhancements of the complex algebraic geometry theorem proving subsystem in GeoGebra for automated proofs in Euclidean geometry, concerning the extension of numerous GeoGebra tools with proof capabilities. As a result, a number of elementary theorems can be proven by using GeoGebra’s intuitive user interface on various computer architectures including native Java and web based systems with JavaScript. We also provide a test suite for benchmarking our results with 200 test cases.
